solution_line_template: Start by finding how many fish were in the aquarium on the third day {initial_fish} * {doubling_factor} * {doubling_factor} = <<{initial_fish}*{doubling_factor}*{doubling_factor}={fish_day_3_before_removal}>>{fish_day_3_before_removal}.

On day three, Jason took out one-third of the fish {fish_day_3_before_removal} / {removal_divisor_day_3} = <<{fish_day_3_before_removal}/{removal_divisor_day_3}={fish_removed_day_3}>>{fish_removed_day_3}.
So at the end of day three, he has {fish_day_3_before_removal} - {fish_removed_day_3} = <<{fish_day_3_before_removal}-{fish_removed_day_3}={fish_end_day_3}>>{fish_end_day_3} fish.
On day five he has {fish_end_day_3} * {doubling_factor} * {doubling_factor} = {fish_day_5_before_removal} fish, but he takes out one-fourth.
So at the end of day five, he has {fish_day_5_before_removal} - {fish_removed_day_5} = <<{fish_day_5_before_removal}-{fish_removed_day_5}={fish_end_day_5}>>{fish_end_day_5} fish.
On day seven he has {fish_end_day_5} * {doubling_factor} * {doubling_factor} = <<{fish_end_day_5}*{doubling_factor}*{doubling_factor}={fish_day_7_before_addition}>>{fish_day_7_before_addition} fish.
He adds in {added_fish_day_7} more, so he has {fish_day_7_before_addition} + {added_fish_day_7} = <<{fish_day_7_before_addition}+{added_fish_day_7}={total_fish}>>{total_fish} fish in total.
